Using tau rather than pi certainly simplifies many equations, and I like that. I also like fundamentals which are easy to remember. I find it easy to remember that pi is the ratio of the full distance around a circle (circumference) to the full distance across the circle (diameter). More generally, pi is the ratio of a given proportion of the circumference to the same proportion of the diameter. That seems tidy. If we prefer the simplification of equations, then using tau seems like a great idea (in most cases, where tau is not already used as a conmon variable in the equation (or related equations).

It makes a lot more sense to me to use Tau = 6.28... as the basic circle constant rather than using Pi = 3.14....  First, Tau relates the circumference of a circle to the circle's radius, rather than Pi which relates the circumference to double the radius (i.e., the diameter).  Second, when expressing angles in radians, Tau is one full 360 degree revolution, which seems more natural to me than expressing 360 degrees as 2*Pi, especially when you have to think about what is meant by fractions like Pi/2 or Tau/4.

I don’t think we need to fight over which is the “best” in the real world because they both have value, but I will tell you that using tau is FAR more intuitive for students when they first start learning about trigonometry, the unit circle, etc. My sister was struggling for weeks and was breaking down because she couldn’t understand what was with 2pi all over the place, the unit circle was confusing because going up a quarter (90 degrees) was pi/2 radians, etc. Her fundamental misunderstanding was that a full period for sin is 2pi radians, so pi radians only covers half a unit circle, which is just unintuitive for new students. Once I taught her how everything works in tao then she had a massive lightbulb moment and suddenly it made sense and it only took an afternoon, because it does make sense in that context, 1 tau radians = 1 revolution around the unit circle. This makes everything else fall into place much more naturally. Once she understood this then the traditional way made more sense, but there’s this awkward extra step in thinking when using pi, especially for students. I remember being massively confused by the same thing and I’m sure if I had been taught the fundamentals using tao then it would have been a lot more clear to me as well.

I still believe using the constant Tau = 6.28... would make trigonometry much easier for students that are previously unfamiliar with angles and functions acting on angles. Because the idea that pi/2 is not half a turn or pi/3 is not a third of a turn around the circle seems to lead students to make several mistakes just because of this arbitrary notation they likely JUST learned about. After that, idgaf what people use, though it would logically follow that you continue using Tau for consistency. Otherwise, I believe engineers should use Pi (=3.14...) because diameter and circumference are direct measurements while radius is an abstract concept relative to diameter, however, I believe mathematicians should use Tau because the concept of a perfect circle in some space comes about from a given center and radius, hence the length of the border line should be taken relative to its radius. But given how many people start hating mathematics around trig level, I think making calculations simpler by using Tau would help maintain a student's interest in math, and that's what I really care about in this argument.

The real reason for adopting tau is for learning in schools where the less mathematically gifted are. Learning basic trigonometry is much more intuitive with the circle constant being tau. The period of a sin wave is 1*tau. The full revolution is 1*tau. A quarter of the circumference of a circle is tau/4.
sin(x)=sin(x+0*tau), cos(x)=sin(x-tau/4), -sin(x)=sin(x-tau/2), -cos(x)=sin(x-3/4*tau), sin(x)=sin(x-1*tau)
Those things really matter for students who start to learn trigonometry.

pi/4 = .7854 and pi/6 = .5236 are much more useful for some calculations involving areas and volumes. For instance the volume of a sphere is .5236 times the regular box that contains it (RBTCI). The volume of any spheroid (prolate or oblate) is .5236 x RBTCI. If you stretch half the box and make an egg shape it's volume is .5236 x RBTCI ... the same is true of very many examples. Same thing for 2D areas using .7854 time the regular rectangle that contains it. As an added bonus, the rounding off error is extremely favorable to real world calculations ... and ... each of the two numbers makes an easily remembered square on a calculator keypad (7854 anf 5236).
Unfortunately this does not work for perimeters of 2D circle related areas or surfaces of 3D volumes. :o(

This is exactly why I could never understand the obsession with changing the constant from "pi" to "tau." Its just an arbitrary choice. Why is that we're limiting ourselves to arbitrary choices. No one is stopping anyone from using tau. It honestly kind of irritated me, and it failed to do the very thing it claimed to solve: help people learn.

If students aren't taught to think interchangeably about these things, then "tau" won't be a solution at all. Its not even that I thought the arguments for "tau" were wrong; I think people should be encouraged to think about "tau," but to argue that a constant "ought" to be this or that is foolish. You might as well argue that it makes more "sense" to use base 12 (jokes on me, because people do argue for that). Sure, base 12 is helpful for loads of circumstances, but it really only shifts those problems elsewhere.

If we just adopt one standard in favor of another, then we're not helping students. What we need to do is to hinder ridgid thinking, and encourage people to think about the same problems from multiple different perspectives. But that actually requires teachers to teach, so we can't have that. It really irritates me how people think complex problems have simple solutions. That might sound oxymoronic since the goal in math is to have simple solutions, but the truth is that any solution in math is merely the appearance of a simple solution. We like to forget what we already know.

A lot of people seem to completely misunderstand the real point of τ.
It's completely uninteresting whether it makes formulas "look cleaner" or not, that's an extremely trivial point, and I have no idea why people even care about something that utterly pointless.
The REAL purpose of τ is that it would make more sense for beginners.
It's much easier to grasp the fact that it actually represents a full revolution instead of half a revolution, and this will make people who are starting out in Trigonometry feel more comfortable with that subject right off the bat.

Intuition for beginners is like rewriting a confusing textbook so that it's easier to follow - "cleaner formulas" is like changing the front cover of that book without rewriting it.
